```java
public class UserController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)
ERROR Line 512:5
REST endpoint 'updateCustomerStatus' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'updateCustomerStatus' (GET) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - No authentication
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        // Anyone can access this!
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. JAX-RS with @RolesAllowed** (Recommended):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    @RolesAllowed({"admin", "user"})  // Add this!
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**2. Spring with @PreAuthorize**:
```java
@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/users")
public class UserController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

ERROR Line 32:5
REST endpoint 'getAddToCartJsonAnalytics' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'getAddToCartJsonAnalytics' (POST) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations

```java
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)
ERROR Line 50:5
REST endpoint 'getAddAddonJsonAnalytics' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'getAddAddonJsonAnalytics' (POST) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - No authentication
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        // Anyone can access this!
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. JAX-RS with @RolesAllowed** (Recommended):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    @RolesAllowed({"admin", "user"})  // Add this!
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**2. Spring with @PreAuthorize**:
```java
@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/users")
public class UserController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

```bash

# Test with auth
```

- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)
ERROR Line 157:5
REST endpoint 'getCheckoutStepSubstitutionJsonAnalytics' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'getCheckoutStepSubstitutionJsonAnalytics' (POST) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - No authentication
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        // Anyone can access this!
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. JAX-RS with @RolesAllowed** (Recommended):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    @RolesAllowed({"admin", "user"})  // Add this!
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**2. Spring with @PreAuthorize**:
```java
@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/users")
public class UserController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)

```java
public class UserController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)
ERROR Line 64:5
REST endpoint 'updateOrder' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'updateOrder' (PUT) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - No authentication
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        // Anyone can access this!
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. JAX-RS with @RolesAllowed** (Recommended):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    @RolesAllowed({"admin", "user"})  // Add this!
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**2. Spring with @PreAuthorize**:
```java
@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/users")
public class UserController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml

    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>

        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
```

```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)
ERROR Line 138:5
REST endpoint 'approveOrder' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'approveOrder' (PUT) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - No authentication
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        // Anyone can access this!
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. JAX-RS with @RolesAllowed** (Recommended):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    @RolesAllowed({"admin", "user"})  // Add this!
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**2. Spring with @PreAuthorize**:
```java
@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/users")
public class UserController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)

ERROR Line 57:33

security.hardcoded-credentials Security Issues
Show details 
See HardcodedCredentialsInspection for full documentation.

Variable: JVM_CREDENTIAL
Type: Credential
Masked Value: ch**********or

Use environment variables or external configuration instead.
ERROR Line 61:5
REST endpoint 'channelGeneratorGet' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'channelGeneratorGet' (GET) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - No authentication

    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        // Anyone can access this!

    }
```

**Correct Patterns**:

WARNING Line 69:36
Parameter 'type' used without null check
config.component-parameter-null Configuration Problems
Show details 
The component parameter 'type' is accessed via getParameter()
and stored in variable 'channelType', but used without null checking.

**Risk**: HIGH - NullPointerException if parameter not configured

**Why This Happens**:
- Parameter not configured in CMS UI
- Typo in parameter name
- Component used in different context without configuration
- Configuration not published yet
- Parameter removed during refactoring

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ⚠️ PROBLEM - No null check
String value = getParameter("myParam");
result.setText(value.toUpperCase()); // NPE if value is null!
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. Simple Null Check** (Recommended):
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
if (value != null) {
    result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
} else {
    // Provide default or skip
    result.setText("Default Value");
}
```

**2. Early Return**:
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
if (value == null) {
    logger.warn("Parameter 'myParam' not configured");
    return;
}
result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
```

**3. Default Value**:
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
String safeValue = (value != null) ? value : "defaultValue";
result.setText(safeValue.toUpperCase());
```

**4. Optional Pattern** (Modern Java):
```java
Optional.ofNullable(getParameter("myParam"))
    .map(String::toUpperCase)
    .ifPresent(result::setText);
```

**5. Apache Commons** (if available):
```java
String value = StringUtils.defaultString(getParameter("myParam"), "default");
result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
```

**Best Practices**:
- Document required parameters in component class JavaDoc
- Log warnings when required parameters are missing
- Provide sensible defaults where possible
- Use parameter validation in doBeforeRender()
- Consider creating a ParametersInfo class with validated parameters

**Example: Robust Parameter Handling**:
```java
@Override
public void doBeforeRender(HstRequest request, HstResponse response) {
    String title = getParameter("title");
    String limit = getParameter("limit");

    // Validate required parameters
    if (title == null) {
        logger.warn("Required parameter 'title' not configured for component {}",
            request.getRequestContext().getResolvedSiteMapItem().getHstComponentConfiguration().getName());
        request.setAttribute("error", "Component not properly configured");
        return;
    }

    // Optional parameter with default
    int maxItems = 10;
    if (limit != null) {
        try {
            maxItems = Integer.parseInt(limit);
        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
            logger.warn("Invalid limit parameter: {}", limit);
        }
    }

    request.setAttribute("title", title);
    request.setAttribute("maxItems", maxItems);
}
```

**Common HST Parameters to Check**:
- Document picker paths
- Query parameters
- Display settings (limit, offset)
- Configuration flags
- Custom component settings

**Related Community Issues**:
- NullPointerException in component rendering
- "Component not displaying" (due to NPE in doBeforeRender)
- Parameters working locally but not on server

**HST Component Configuration**:
Component parameters are configured in repository at:
```
/hst:hst/hst:configurations/[project]/hst:components/[component]
  + hst:parameternames = ['param1', 'param2']
  + hst:parametervalues = ['value1', 'value2']
```

**References**:
- [HST Component Development](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [Component Parameters Guide](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
WARNING Line 71:36
Parameter 'name' used without null check
config.component-parameter-null Configuration Problems
Show details 
The component parameter 'name' is accessed via getParameter()
and stored in variable 'channelName', but used without null checking.

**Risk**: HIGH - NullPointerException if parameter not configured

**Why This Happens**:
- Parameter not configured in CMS UI
- Typo in parameter name
- Component used in different context without configuration
- Configuration not published yet
- Parameter removed during refactoring

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ⚠️ PROBLEM - No null check
String value = getParameter("myParam");
result.setText(value.toUpperCase()); // NPE if value is null!
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. Simple Null Check** (Recommended):
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
if (value != null) {
    result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
} else {
    // Provide default or skip
    result.setText("Default Value");
}
```

**2. Early Return**:
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
if (value == null) {
    logger.warn("Parameter 'myParam' not configured");
    return;
}
result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
```

**3. Default Value**:
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
String safeValue = (value != null) ? value : "defaultValue";
result.setText(safeValue.toUpperCase());
```

**4. Optional Pattern** (Modern Java):
```java
Optional.ofNullable(getParameter("myParam"))
    .map(String::toUpperCase)
    .ifPresent(result::setText);
```

**5. Apache Commons** (if available):
```java
String value = StringUtils.defaultString(getParameter("myParam"), "default");
result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
```

**Best Practices**:
- Document required parameters in component class JavaDoc
- Log warnings when required parameters are missing
- Provide sensible defaults where possible
- Use parameter validation in doBeforeRender()
- Consider creating a ParametersInfo class with validated parameters

**Example: Robust Parameter Handling**:
```java
@Override
public void doBeforeRender(HstRequest request, HstResponse response) {
    String title = getParameter("title");
    String limit = getParameter("limit");

    // Validate required parameters
    if (title == null) {
        logger.warn("Required parameter 'title' not configured for component {}",
            request.getRequestContext().getResolvedSiteMapItem().getHstComponentConfiguration().getName());
        request.setAttribute("error", "Component not properly configured");
        return;
    }

    // Optional parameter with default
    int maxItems = 10;
    if (limit != null) {
        try {
            maxItems = Integer.parseInt(limit);
        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
            logger.warn("Invalid limit parameter: {}", limit);
        }
    }

    request.setAttribute("title", title);
    request.setAttribute("maxItems", maxItems);
}
```

**Common HST Parameters to Check**:
- Document picker paths
- Query parameters
- Display settings (limit, offset)
- Configuration flags
- Custom component settings

**Related Community Issues**:
- NullPointerException in component rendering
- "Component not displaying" (due to NPE in doBeforeRender)
- Parameters working locally but not on server

**HST Component Configuration**:
Component parameters are configured in repository at:
```
/hst:hst/hst:configurations/[project]/hst:components/[component]
  + hst:parameternames = ['param1', 'param2']
  + hst:parametervalues = ['value1', 'value2']
```

**References**:
- [HST Component Development](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [Component Parameters Guide](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
ERROR Line 87:5
REST endpoint 'changeInheritance' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'changeInheritance' (GET) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - No authentication
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        // Anyone can access this!
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. JAX-RS with @RolesAllowed** (Recommended):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    @RolesAllowed({"admin", "user"})  // Add this!
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**2. Spring with @PreAuthorize**:
```java
@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/users")
public class UserController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)
ERROR Line 156:5
REST endpoint 'addPropertyToNodes' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'addPropertyToNodes' (GET) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - No authentication
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        // Anyone can access this!
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. JAX-RS with @RolesAllowed** (Recommended):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    @RolesAllowed({"admin", "user"})  // Add this!
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**2. Spring with @PreAuthorize**:
```java
@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/users")
public class UserController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)
WARNING Line 172:36
Parameter 'PATH_PARAMETER' used without null check
config.component-parameter-null Configuration Problems
Show details 
The component parameter 'PATH_PARAMETER' is accessed via getParameter()
and stored in variable 'pathParam', but used without null checking.

**Risk**: HIGH - NullPointerException if parameter not configured

**Why This Happens**:
- Parameter not configured in CMS UI
- Typo in parameter name
- Component used in different context without configuration
- Configuration not published yet
- Parameter removed during refactoring

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ⚠️ PROBLEM - No null check
String value = getParameter("myParam");
result.setText(value.toUpperCase()); // NPE if value is null!
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. Simple Null Check** (Recommended):
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
if (value != null) {
    result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
} else {
    // Provide default or skip
    result.setText("Default Value");
}
```

**2. Early Return**:
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
if (value == null) {
    logger.warn("Parameter 'myParam' not configured");
    return;
}
result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
```

**3. Default Value**:
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
String safeValue = (value != null) ? value : "defaultValue";
result.setText(safeValue.toUpperCase());
```

**4. Optional Pattern** (Modern Java):
```java
Optional.ofNullable(getParameter("myParam"))
    .map(String::toUpperCase)
    .ifPresent(result::setText);
```

**5. Apache Commons** (if available):
```java
String value = StringUtils.defaultString(getParameter("myParam"), "default");
result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
```

**Best Practices**:
- Document required parameters in component class JavaDoc
- Log warnings when required parameters are missing
- Provide sensible defaults where possible
- Use parameter validation in doBeforeRender()
- Consider creating a ParametersInfo class with validated parameters

**Example: Robust Parameter Handling**:
```java
@Override
public void doBeforeRender(HstRequest request, HstResponse response) {
    String title = getParameter("title");
    String limit = getParameter("limit");

    // Validate required parameters
    if (title == null) {
        logger.warn("Required parameter 'title' not configured for component {}",
            request.getRequestContext().getResolvedSiteMapItem().getHstComponentConfiguration().getName());
        request.setAttribute("error", "Component not properly configured");
        return;
    }

    // Optional parameter with default
    int maxItems = 10;
    if (limit != null) {
        try {
            maxItems = Integer.parseInt(limit);
        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
            logger.warn("Invalid limit parameter: {}", limit);
        }
    }

    request.setAttribute("title", title);
    request.setAttribute("maxItems", maxItems);
}
```

**Common HST Parameters to Check**:
- Document picker paths
- Query parameters
- Display settings (limit, offset)
- Configuration flags
- Custom component settings

**Related Community Issues**:
- NullPointerException in component rendering
- "Component not displaying" (due to NPE in doBeforeRender)
- Parameters working locally but not on server

**HST Component Configuration**:
Component parameters are configured in repository at:
```
/hst:hst/hst:configurations/[project]/hst:components/[component]
  + hst:parameternames = ['param1', 'param2']
  + hst:parametervalues = ['value1', 'value2']
```

**References**:
- [HST Component Development](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [Component Parameters Guide](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
WARNING Line 173:37
Parameter 'NODES_PARAMETER' used without null check
config.component-parameter-null Configuration Problems
Show details 
The component parameter 'NODES_PARAMETER' is accessed via getParameter()
and stored in variable 'nodesParam', but used without null checking.

**Risk**: HIGH - NullPointerException if parameter not configured

**Why This Happens**:
- Parameter not configured in CMS UI
- Typo in parameter name
- Component used in different context without configuration
- Configuration not published yet
- Parameter removed during refactoring

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ⚠️ PROBLEM - No null check
String value = getParameter("myParam");
result.setText(value.toUpperCase()); // NPE if value is null!
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. Simple Null Check** (Recommended):
```java

    result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
} else {
    // Provide default or skip
    result.setText("Default Value");
}
```

**2. Early Return**:
```java

    logger.warn("Parameter 'myParam' not configured");
    return;
}

```

**3. Default Value**:
```java

result.setText(safeValue.toUpperCase());
```

**4. Optional Pattern** (Modern Java):
```java

    .map(String::toUpperCase)
    .ifPresent(result::setText);
```

**5. Apache Commons** (if available):
```java

result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
```

**Best Practices**:
- Document required parameters in component class JavaDoc
- Log warnings when required parameters are missing
- Provide sensible defaults where possible
- Use parameter validation in doBeforeRender()
- Consider creating a ParametersInfo class with validated parameters

**Example: Robust Parameter Handling**:
```java
@Override
public void doBeforeRender(HstRequest request, HstResponse response) {
    String title = getParameter("title");
    String limit = getParameter("limit");

    // Validate required parameters
    if (title == null) {
        logger.warn("Required parameter 'title' not configured for component {}",
            request.getRequestContext().getResolvedSiteMapItem().getHstComponentConfiguration().getName());
        request.setAttribute("error", "Component not properly configured");
        return;
    }

    // Optional parameter with default
    int maxItems = 10;
    if (limit != null) {
        try {
            maxItems = Integer.parseInt(limit);
        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
            logger.warn("Invalid limit parameter: {}", limit);
        }
    }

    request.setAttribute("title", title);
    request.setAttribute("maxItems", maxItems);
}
```

- Document picker paths
- Query parameters
- Display settings (limit, offset)
- Configuration flags
- Custom component settings

- NullPointerException in component rendering
- "Component not displaying" (due to NPE in doBeforeRender)
- Parameters working locally but not on server

```
  + hst:parametervalues = ['value1', 'value2']
```

- [Component Parameters Guide](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)

and stored in variable 'nameParam', but used without null checking.

- Parameter not configured in CMS UI
- Typo in parameter name
- Component used in different context without configuration
- Configuration not published yet

- Document required parameters in component class JavaDoc
- Log warnings when required parameters are missing
- Provide sensible defaults where possible
- Use parameter validation in doBeforeRender()
- Consider creating a ParametersInfo class with validated parameters

**Example: Robust Parameter Handling**:
```java
@Override
public void doBeforeRender(HstRequest request, HstResponse response) {
    String title = getParameter("title");
    String limit = getParameter("limit");

    // Validate required parameters
    if (title == null) {
        logger.warn("Required parameter 'title' not configured for component {}",
            request.getRequestContext().getResolvedSiteMapItem().getHstComponentConfiguration().getName());
        request.setAttribute("error", "Component not properly configured");
        return;
    }

    // Optional parameter with default
    int maxItems = 10;
    if (limit != null) {
        try {
            maxItems = Integer.parseInt(limit);
        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
            logger.warn("Invalid limit parameter: {}", limit);
        }
    }

    request.setAttribute("title", title);
    request.setAttribute("maxItems", maxItems);
}
```

config.component-parameter-null Configuration Problems
Show details 
The component parameter 'VALUE_PARAMETER' is accessed via getParameter()
and stored in variable 'valueParam', but used without null checking.

**Why This Happens**:
- Parameter not configured in CMS UI
- Typo in parameter name
- Component used in different context without configuration
- Configuration not published yet

ERROR Line 219:5
REST endpoint 'addRequestAccountFolder' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'addRequestAccountFolder' (GET) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

**Problem Pattern**:
```java

    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        // Anyone can access this!
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. JAX-RS with @RolesAllowed** (Recommended):
```java

    @RolesAllowed({"admin", "user"})  // Add this!
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**2. Spring with @PreAuthorize**:
```java
@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/users")
public class UserController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)
ERROR Line 280:5
REST endpoint 'removeNodeFromChannelsConfig' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'removeNodeFromChannelsConfig' (GET) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - No authentication
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        // Anyone can access this!
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. JAX-RS with @RolesAllowed** (Recommended):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    @RolesAllowed({"admin", "user"})  // Add this!
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**2. Spring with @PreAuthorize**:
```java
@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/users")
public class UserController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)

REST endpoint 'updateRequestAccountFolderAllowedDocuments' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'updateRequestAccountFolderAllowedDocuments' (GET) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

**Problem Pattern**:
```java

    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        // Anyone can access this!
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. JAX-RS with @RolesAllowed** (Recommended):
```java

    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    @RolesAllowed({"admin", "user"})  // Add this!
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**2. Spring with @PreAuthorize**:
```java
@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/users")

    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints

    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml

    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

```bash

# Test with auth
```

- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations

Show details 
REST endpoint 'updateSelectedStore' (POST) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks

**Why This Is Dangerous**:

- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)
ERROR Line 74:2
REST endpoint 'clearCart' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'clearCart' (DELETE) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - No authentication
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        // Anyone can access this!
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. JAX-RS with @RolesAllowed** (Recommended):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    @RolesAllowed({"admin", "user"})  // Add this!
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**2. Spring with @PreAuthorize**:
```java
@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/users")
public class UserController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

```java
    }

    }
```
```java
}
```

```java
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

```java

        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")

    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

```java

@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public

    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

- `developer` - Developers

- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access
