```xml
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)
ERROR Line 214:2
REST endpoint 'addItemsToCart' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'addItemsToCart' (POST) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - No authentication
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        // Anyone can access this!
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. JAX-RS with @RolesAllowed** (Recommended):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    @RolesAllowed({"admin", "user"})  // Add this!
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**2. Spring with @PreAuthorize**:
```java
@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/users")
public class UserController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations

```java
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
```

```java
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")

    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

```java

@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public

    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers

- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

```bash
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)
ERROR Line 335:2
REST endpoint 'getPunchoutCart' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'getPunchoutCart' (GET) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - No authentication
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        // Anyone can access this!
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. JAX-RS with @RolesAllowed** (Recommended):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    @RolesAllowed({"admin", "user"})  // Add this!
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**2. Spring with @PreAuthorize**:
```java
@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/users")
public class UserController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)

../johnstone-bloomreach-v14--latest-code/johnstonesupply-cms/site/components/src/main/java/com/johnstonesupply/cms/servlet/MessageResource.java

4 issue(s)
ERROR Line 56:2
REST endpoint 'fetchAlertMessage' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'fetchAlertMessage' (GET) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - No authentication
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        // Anyone can access this!
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. JAX-RS with @RolesAllowed** (Recommended):
```java

    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    @RolesAllowed({"admin", "user"})  // Add this!
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**2. Spring with @PreAuthorize**:
```java
@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/users")
public class UserController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)
WARNING Line 63:21
Parameter 'ALERT_MAIN_STORE_CODE' used without null check
config.component-parameter-null Configuration Problems
Show details 
The component parameter 'ALERT_MAIN_STORE_CODE' is accessed via getParameter()
and stored in variable 'mainStoreCode', but used without null checking.

**Risk**: HIGH - NullPointerException if parameter not configured

**Why This Happens**:
- Parameter not configured in CMS UI
- Typo in parameter name
- Component used in different context without configuration
- Configuration not published yet
- Parameter removed during refactoring

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ⚠️ PROBLEM - No null check
String value = getParameter("myParam");
result.setText(value.toUpperCase()); // NPE if value is null!
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. Simple Null Check** (Recommended):
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
if (value != null) {
    result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
} else {
    // Provide default or skip
    result.setText("Default Value");
}
```

**2. Early Return**:
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
if (value == null) {
    logger.warn("Parameter 'myParam' not configured");
    return;
}
result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
```

**3. Default Value**:
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
String safeValue = (value != null) ? value : "defaultValue";
result.setText(safeValue.toUpperCase());
```

**4. Optional Pattern** (Modern Java):
```java
Optional.ofNullable(getParameter("myParam"))
    .map(String::toUpperCase)
    .ifPresent(result::setText);
```

**5. Apache Commons** (if available):
```java
String value = StringUtils.defaultString(getParameter("myParam"), "default");
result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
```

**Best Practices**:
- Document required parameters in component class JavaDoc
- Log warnings when required parameters are missing
- Provide sensible defaults where possible
- Use parameter validation in doBeforeRender()
- Consider creating a ParametersInfo class with validated parameters

**Example: Robust Parameter Handling**:
```java
@Override
public void doBeforeRender(HstRequest request, HstResponse response) {
    String title = getParameter("title");
    String limit = getParameter("limit");

    // Validate required parameters
    if (title == null) {
        logger.warn("Required parameter 'title' not configured for component {}",
            request.getRequestContext().getResolvedSiteMapItem().getHstComponentConfiguration().getName());
        request.setAttribute("error", "Component not properly configured");
        return;
    }

    // Optional parameter with default
    int maxItems = 10;
    if (limit != null) {
        try {
            maxItems = Integer.parseInt(limit);
        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
            logger.warn("Invalid limit parameter: {}", limit);
        }
    }

    request.setAttribute("title", title);
    request.setAttribute("maxItems", maxItems);
}
```

**Common HST Parameters to Check**:
- Document picker paths
- Query parameters
- Display settings (limit, offset)
- Configuration flags
- Custom component settings

**Related Community Issues**:
- NullPointerException in component rendering
- "Component not displaying" (due to NPE in doBeforeRender)
- Parameters working locally but not on server

**HST Component Configuration**:
Component parameters are configured in repository at:
```
/hst:hst/hst:configurations/[project]/hst:components/[component]
  + hst:parameternames = ['param1', 'param2']
  + hst:parametervalues = ['value1', 'value2']
```

**References**:
- [HST Component Development](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [Component Parameters Guide](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)

security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'fetchAlertMessageList' (GET) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

**Problem Pattern**:
```java

    }
}
```

```java
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**2. Spring with @PreAuthorize**:
```java

    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java

    @Path("/{id}")

        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml

    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

```bash

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)

ERROR Line 97:24
Parameter 'ALERT_MAIN_STORE_CODE' used inline without null check
config.component-parameter-null Configuration Problems
Show details 
The component parameter 'ALERT_MAIN_STORE_CODE' is accessed and used immediately
without any null checking. This will cause a NullPointerException if the
parameter is not configured.

**Problem**: Inline usage without assignment makes it impossible to null-check

**Example**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - Inline usage
result.setText(getParameter("title").toUpperCase());
// NPE if 'title' parameter not configured!
```

**Solution**: Assign to variable first, then null-check:
```java
String title = getParameter("title");
if (title != null) {
    result.setText(title.toUpperCase());
} else {
    result.setText("Untitled");
}
```

See the main documentation for comprehensive examples and best practices.

../johnstone-bloomreach-v14--latest-code/johnstonesupply-cms/site/components/src/main/java/com/johnstonesupply/cms/servlet/AccountManagementResource.java

ERROR Line 42:33
Hardcoded Password: 'PASSWORD'
security.hardcoded-credentials Security Issues
Show details 
See HardcodedCredentialsInspection for full documentation.

Variable: PASSWORD
Type: Password
Masked Value: pa****rd

Use environment variables or external configuration instead.

security.hardcoded-credentials Security Issues
Show details 
See HardcodedCredentialsInspection for full documentation.

Variable: PASSWORD_CONFIRMATION
Type: Password
Masked Value: pa****************on

Use environment variables or external configuration instead.
ERROR Line 59:5
REST endpoint 'updateAccountUsers' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'updateAccountUsers' (PUT) does not have authentication configured.

**Why This Is Dangerous**:

ERROR Line 88:5
REST endpoint 'addNewUserToAccount' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'addNewUserToAccount' (POST) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)
ERROR Line 122:5
REST endpoint 'updateAccountUserDetails' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'updateAccountUserDetails' (PUT) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - No authentication
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        // Anyone can access this!
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. JAX-RS with @RolesAllowed** (Recommended):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    @RolesAllowed({"admin", "user"})  // Add this!
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**2. Spring with @PreAuthorize**:
```java
@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/users")
public class UserController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)

REST endpoint 'updateAccountDetails' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'updateAccountDetails' (PUT) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations

- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

```java

        // Anyone can access this!
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

```java

        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

```java

    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints

    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml

    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>

    </auth-constraint>
```

REST endpoint 'getShippingAddresses' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'getShippingAddresses' (GET) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations

- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations

```java
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
```

- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)
ERROR Line 112:2
REST endpoint 'findPartstockByGuid' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'findPartstockByGuid' (GET) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - No authentication
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        // Anyone can access this!
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. JAX-RS with @RolesAllowed** (Recommended):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    @RolesAllowed({"admin", "user"})  // Add this!
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**2. Spring with @PreAuthorize**:
```java
@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/users")
public class UserController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations

```java
    }
}
```

```java
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

```java

        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers

- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations

```xml
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)
ERROR Line 248:2
REST endpoint 'updatePartstock' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'updatePartstock' (PUT) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - No authentication
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        // Anyone can access this!
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. JAX-RS with @RolesAllowed** (Recommended):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    @RolesAllowed({"admin", "user"})  // Add this!
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**2. Spring with @PreAuthorize**:
```java
@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/users")
public class UserController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations

- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

```java
    }
```

```java
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
```

```java
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers

- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

```bash
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)
ERROR Line 432:2
REST endpoint 'createPartstocksExcelFile' missing authentication
security.rest-authentication Security Issues
Show details 
REST endpoint 'createPartstocksExcelFile' (GET) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - No authentication
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        // Anyone can access this!
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. JAX-RS with @RolesAllowed** (Recommended):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    @RolesAllowed({"admin", "user"})  // Add this!
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }
}
```

**2. Spring with @PreAuthorize**:
```java
@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/users")
public class UserController {
    @GetMapping("/{id}")
    @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN') or hasRole('USER')")  // Add this!
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

**3. Class-Level Security** (applies to all methods):
```java
@Path("/api/users")
@RolesAllowed("user")  // Applies to all endpoints
public class UserResource {
    @GET
    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

**4. Manual Authentication Check** (when annotations don't work):
```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

**Common Bloomreach Roles**:
- `admin` - Full administrative access
- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers
- `xm.rest.user` - REST API access
- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

**Configuration**:
Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:
```xml
<security-constraint>
    <web-resource-collection>
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>
    <auth-constraint>
        <role-name>xm.rest.user</role-name>
    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

**Testing**:
```bash
# Test without auth (should fail)
curl http://localhost:8080/api/users/123

# Test with auth
curl -u admin:admin http://localhost:8080/api/users/123
```

**When to Use Each Approach**:
- @RolesAllowed: Standard approach for most endpoints
- @PermitAll: Explicitly public endpoints (health checks, documentation)
- @DenyAll: Deprecated or disabled endpoints
- Manual check: Custom authentication logic

**Related Issues**:
- CORS configuration for cross-origin requests
- CSRF protection for state-changing operations
- Rate limiting for public APIs

**References**:
- [JAX-RS Security](https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/security-jaxrs002.htm)
- [Bloomreach REST API Security](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [OWASP API Security Top 10](https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/)

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations

- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

```java
    public User getUser(@PathVariable String id) {
        return userService.getUser(id);
    }
}
```

```java

    @Path("/{id}")
    public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id) {
        return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
    }

    @POST
    @RolesAllowed("admin")  // Override for specific method
    public Response createUser(User user) {
        return Response.ok(userService.create(user)).build();
    }
}
```

```java
@GET
@Path("/{id}")
public Response getUser(@PathParam("id") String id, @Context SecurityContext sc) {
    // Manual check
    if (sc.getUserPrincipal() == null) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.UNAUTHORIZED).build();
    }

    // Check role
    if (!sc.isUserInRole("user")) {
        return Response.status(Response.Status.FORBIDDEN).build();
    }

    return Response.ok(userService.getUser(id)).build();
}
```

**5. Public Endpoint** (explicitly mark as public):
```java
@GET
@Path("/health")
@PermitAll  // Explicitly mark as public
public Response healthCheck() {
    return Response.ok("OK").build();
}
```

- `author` - Content authors
- `editor` - Content editors
- `developer` - Developers

- `xm.rest.admin` - REST API administrative access

Ensure authentication is configured in web.xml:

```xml
        <web-resource-name>REST API</web-resource-name>
        <url-pattern>/api/*</url-pattern>
    </web-resource-collection>

    </auth-constraint>
</security-constraint>
```

REST endpoint 'getBrands' missing authentication

Show details 
REST endpoint 'getBrands' (GET) does not have authentication configured.

**Security Risk**: CRITICAL - Unauthorized access to API endpoints

**Why This Is Dangerous**:
- API endpoints are directly accessible via HTTP
- No authentication means anyone can call the endpoint
- Can expose sensitive data or operations
- Common target for automated attacks
- May violate compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)

../johnstone-bloomreach-v14--latest-code/johnstonesupply-cms/site/components/src/main/java/com/johnstonesupply/cms/auth/JsLogoutSuccessHandler.java

1 issue(s)
ERROR Line 41:28
Parameter 'PARTSTOCK_LOGOUT' used inline without null check
config.component-parameter-null Configuration Problems
Show details 
The component parameter 'PARTSTOCK_LOGOUT' is accessed and used immediately
without any null checking. This will cause a NullPointerException if the
parameter is not configured.

**Problem**: Inline usage without assignment makes it impossible to null-check

**Example**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - Inline usage
result.setText(getParameter("title").toUpperCase());
// NPE if 'title' parameter not configured!
```

**Solution**: Assign to variable first, then null-check:
```java
String title = getParameter("title");
if (title != null) {
    result.setText(title.toUpperCase());
} else {
    result.setText("Untitled");
}
```

See the main documentation for comprehensive examples and best practices.

../johnstone-bloomreach-v14--latest-code/johnstonesupply-cms/site/components/src/main/java/com/johnstonesupply/cms/auth/JsSpringSecurityValve.java

1 issue(s)
ERROR Line 51:20
JCR Session 'session' is not closed in finally block
repository.session-leak Repository Tier Issues
Show details 
The JCR session 'session' is created but not properly closed in a finally block.
This can lead to session pool exhaustion and memory leaks.

**Impact**: High - Can cause application crashes and performance degradation

**Best Practice**: Always close sessions in a finally block or use try-with-resources (Java 7+).

**Example (finally block)**:
```java
Session session = null;
try {
    session = repository.login();
    // ... work with session
} finally {
    if (session != null && session.isLive()) {
        session.logout();
    }
}
```

**Example (try-with-resources, recommended)**:
```java
try (Session session = repository.login()) {
    // ... work with session
} // session automatically closed
```

**Related Community Issues**:
- NoAvailableSessionException - Session pool exhaustion
- OutOfMemoryError - Memory leak from unclosed sessions

**References**:
- [JCR Session Management Best Practices](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [Community Forum: Session Pool Exhaustion](https://community.bloomreach.com/)

../johnstone-bloomreach-v14--latest-code/johnstonesupply-cms/site/components/src/main/java/com/johnstonesupply/cms/auth/SCMUserDetailsValve.java

1 issue(s)
ERROR Line 121:61
Parameter 'group' used inline without null check
config.component-parameter-null Configuration Problems
Show details 
The component parameter 'group' is accessed and used immediately
without any null checking. This will cause a NullPointerException if the
parameter is not configured.

**Problem**: Inline usage without assignment makes it impossible to null-check

**Example**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - Inline usage
result.setText(getParameter("title").toUpperCase());
// NPE if 'title' parameter not configured!
```

**Solution**: Assign to variable first, then null-check:
```java
String title = getParameter("title");
if (title != null) {
    result.setText(title.toUpperCase());
} else {
    result.setText("Untitled");
}
```

See the main documentation for comprehensive examples and best practices.

../johnstone-bloomreach-v14--latest-code/johnstonesupply-cms/site/components/src/main/java/com/johnstonesupply/cms/auth/JsUsernamePasswordAuthenticationFilter.java

6 issue(s)
ERROR Line 72:16
JCR Session 'httpSession' is not closed in finally block
repository.session-leak Repository Tier Issues
Show details 
The JCR session 'httpSession' is created but not properly closed in a finally block.
This can lead to session pool exhaustion and memory leaks.

**Impact**: High - Can cause application crashes and performance degradation

**Best Practice**: Always close sessions in a finally block or use try-with-resources (Java 7+).

**Example (finally block)**:
```java
Session session = null;
try {
    session = repository.login();
    // ... work with session
} finally {
    if (session != null && session.isLive()) {
        session.logout();
    }
}
```

**Example (try-with-resources, recommended)**:
```java
try (Session session = repository.login()) {
    // ... work with session
} // session automatically closed
```

**Related Community Issues**:
- NoAvailableSessionException - Session pool exhaustion
- OutOfMemoryError - Memory leak from unclosed sessions

**References**:
- [JCR Session Management Best Practices](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [Community Forum: Session Pool Exhaustion](https://community.bloomreach.com/)
ERROR Line 98:27
Parameter 'STORE_CODE' used inline without null check
config.component-parameter-null Configuration Problems
Show details 
The component parameter 'STORE_CODE' is accessed and used immediately
without any null checking. This will cause a NullPointerException if the
parameter is not configured.

**Problem**: Inline usage without assignment makes it impossible to null-check

**Example**:
```java
// ❌ PROBLEM - Inline usage
result.setText(getParameter("title").toUpperCase());
// NPE if 'title' parameter not configured!
```

**Solution**: Assign to variable first, then null-check:
```java
String title = getParameter("title");
if (title != null) {
    result.setText(title.toUpperCase());
} else {
    result.setText("Untitled");
}
```

See the main documentation for comprehensive examples and best practices.
ERROR Line 99:7


../johnstone-bloomreach-v14--latest-code/johnstonesupply-cms/site/components/src/main/java/com/johnstonesupply/cms/components/PunchoutQuote.java

4 issue(s)
WARNING Line 39:25
Parameter 'ACTION_PARAM_NAME' used without null check
config.component-parameter-null Configuration Problems
Show details 
The component parameter 'ACTION_PARAM_NAME' is accessed via getParameter()
and stored in variable 'action', but used without null checking.

**Risk**: HIGH - NullPointerException if parameter not configured

**Why This Happens**:
- Parameter not configured in CMS UI
- Typo in parameter name
- Component used in different context without configuration
- Configuration not published yet
- Parameter removed during refactoring

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ⚠️ PROBLEM - No null check
String value = getParameter("myParam");
result.setText(value.toUpperCase()); // NPE if value is null!
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. Simple Null Check** (Recommended):
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
if (value != null) {
    result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
} else {
    // Provide default or skip
    result.setText("Default Value");
}
```

**2. Early Return**:
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
if (value == null) {
    logger.warn("Parameter 'myParam' not configured");
    return;
}
result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
```

**3. Default Value**:
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
String safeValue = (value != null) ? value : "defaultValue";
result.setText(safeValue.toUpperCase());
```

**4. Optional Pattern** (Modern Java):
```java
Optional.ofNullable(getParameter("myParam"))
    .map(String::toUpperCase)
    .ifPresent(result::setText);
```

**5. Apache Commons** (if available):
```java
String value = StringUtils.defaultString(getParameter("myParam"), "default");
result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
```

**Best Practices**:
- Document required parameters in component class JavaDoc
- Log warnings when required parameters are missing
- Provide sensible defaults where possible
- Use parameter validation in doBeforeRender()
- Consider creating a ParametersInfo class with validated parameters

**Example: Robust Parameter Handling**:
```java
@Override
public void doBeforeRender(HstRequest request, HstResponse response) {
    String title = getParameter("title");
    String limit = getParameter("limit");

    // Validate required parameters
    if (title == null) {
        logger.warn("Required parameter 'title' not configured for component {}",
            request.getRequestContext().getResolvedSiteMapItem().getHstComponentConfiguration().getName());
        request.setAttribute("error", "Component not properly configured");
        return;
    }

    // Optional parameter with default
    int maxItems = 10;
    if (limit != null) {
        try {
            maxItems = Integer.parseInt(limit);
        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
            logger.warn("Invalid limit parameter: {}", limit);
        }
    }

    request.setAttribute("title", title);
    request.setAttribute("maxItems", maxItems);
}
```

**Common HST Parameters to Check**:
- Document picker paths
- Query parameters
- Display settings (limit, offset)
- Configuration flags
- Custom component settings

**Related Community Issues**:
- NullPointerException in component rendering
- "Component not displaying" (due to NPE in doBeforeRender)
- Parameters working locally but not on server

**HST Component Configuration**:
Component parameters are configured in repository at:
```
/hst:hst/hst:configurations/[project]/hst:components/[component]
  + hst:parameternames = ['param1', 'param2']
  + hst:parametervalues = ['value1', 'value2']
```

**References**:
- [HST Component Development](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [Component Parameters Guide](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
WARNING Line 48:33
Parameter 'REQUESTED_QUOTE_ID' used without null check
config.component-parameter-null Configuration Problems
Show details 
The component parameter 'REQUESTED_QUOTE_ID' is accessed via getParameter()
and stored in variable 'requestedQuote', but used without null checking.

**Risk**: HIGH - NullPointerException if parameter not configured

**Why This Happens**:
- Parameter not configured in CMS UI
- Typo in parameter name
- Component used in different context without configuration
- Configuration not published yet
- Parameter removed during refactoring

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ⚠️ PROBLEM - No null check
String value = getParameter("myParam");
result.setText(value.toUpperCase()); // NPE if value is null!
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. Simple Null Check** (Recommended):
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
if (value != null) {
    result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
} else {
    // Provide default or skip
    result.setText("Default Value");
}
```

**2. Early Return**:
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
if (value == null) {
    logger.warn("Parameter 'myParam' not configured");
    return;
}
result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
```

**3. Default Value**:
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
String safeValue = (value != null) ? value : "defaultValue";
result.setText(safeValue.toUpperCase());
```

**4. Optional Pattern** (Modern Java):
```java
Optional.ofNullable(getParameter("myParam"))
    .map(String::toUpperCase)
    .ifPresent(result::setText);
```

**5. Apache Commons** (if available):
```java
String value = StringUtils.defaultString(getParameter("myParam"), "default");
result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
```

**Best Practices**:
- Document required parameters in component class JavaDoc
- Log warnings when required parameters are missing
- Provide sensible defaults where possible
- Use parameter validation in doBeforeRender()
- Consider creating a ParametersInfo class with validated parameters

**Example: Robust Parameter Handling**:
```java
@Override
public void doBeforeRender(HstRequest request, HstResponse response) {
    String title = getParameter("title");
    String limit = getParameter("limit");

    // Validate required parameters
    if (title == null) {
        logger.warn("Required parameter 'title' not configured for component {}",
            request.getRequestContext().getResolvedSiteMapItem().getHstComponentConfiguration().getName());
        request.setAttribute("error", "Component not properly configured");
        return;
    }

    // Optional parameter with default
    int maxItems = 10;
    if (limit != null) {
        try {
            maxItems = Integer.parseInt(limit);
        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
            logger.warn("Invalid limit parameter: {}", limit);
        }
    }

    request.setAttribute("title", title);
    request.setAttribute("maxItems", maxItems);
}
```

**Common HST Parameters to Check**:
- Document picker paths
- Query parameters
- Display settings (limit, offset)
- Configuration flags
- Custom component settings

**Related Community Issues**:
- NullPointerException in component rendering
- "Component not displaying" (due to NPE in doBeforeRender)
- Parameters working locally but not on server

**HST Component Configuration**:
Component parameters are configured in repository at:
```
/hst:hst/hst:configurations/[project]/hst:components/[component]
  + hst:parameternames = ['param1', 'param2']
  + hst:parametervalues = ['value1', 'value2']
```

**References**:
- [HST Component Development](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [Component Parameters Guide](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)

- Log warnings when required parameters are missing
- Provide sensible defaults where possible
- Use parameter validation in doBeforeRender()

**Example: Robust Parameter Handling**:
```java
@Override
public void doBeforeRender(HstRequest request, HstResponse response) {
    String title = getParameter("title");
    String limit = getParameter("limit");

    // Validate required parameters
    if (title == null) {
        logger.warn("Required parameter 'title' not configured for component {}",
            request.getRequestContext().getResolvedSiteMapItem().getHstComponentConfiguration().getName());
        request.setAttribute("error", "Component not properly configured");
        return;
    }

    // Optional parameter with default
    int maxItems = 10;
    if (limit != null) {
        try {
            maxItems = Integer.parseInt(limit);
        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
            logger.warn("Invalid limit parameter: {}", limit);
        }
    }

    request.setAttribute("title", title);
    request.setAttribute("maxItems", maxItems);
}
```

**Example: Robust Parameter Handling**:
```java
@Override
public void doBeforeRender(HstRequest request, HstResponse response) {
    String title = getParameter("title");
    String limit = getParameter("limit");

    // Validate required parameters
    if (title == null) {
        logger.warn("Required parameter 'title' not configured for component {}",
            request.getRequestContext().getResolvedSiteMapItem().getHstComponentConfiguration().getName());
        request.setAttribute("error", "Component not properly configured");
        return;
    }

    // Optional parameter with default
    int maxItems = 10;
    if (limit != null) {
        try {
            maxItems = Integer.parseInt(limit);
        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
            logger.warn("Invalid limit parameter: {}", limit);
        }
    }

    request.setAttribute("title", title);
    request.setAttribute("maxItems", maxItems);
}
```

```java
@Override
public void doBeforeRender(HstRequest request, HstResponse response) {
    String title = getParameter("title");
    String limit = getParameter("limit");

    // Validate required parameters
    if (title == null) {
        logger.warn("Required parameter 'title' not configured for component {}",
            request.getRequestContext().getResolvedSiteMapItem().getHstComponentConfiguration().getName());
        request.setAttribute("error", "Component not properly configured");
        return;

    // Optional parameter with default

    if (limit != null) {
        try {
            maxItems = Integer.parseInt(limit);
        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
            logger.warn("Invalid limit parameter: {}", limit);
        }
    }

    request.setAttribute("title", title);
    request.setAttribute("maxItems", maxItems);
}
```

WARNING Line 57:37
Parameter 'request' used without null check
config.component-parameter-null Configuration Problems
Show details 
The component parameter 'request' is accessed via getPublicRequestParameter()
and stored in variable 'entityId', but used without null checking.

**Risk**: HIGH - NullPointerException if parameter not configured

**Why This Happens**:

```java
@Override
public void doBeforeRender(HstRequest request, HstResponse response) {
    String title = getParameter("title");
    String limit = getParameter("limit");

    // Validate required parameters
    if (title == null) {
        logger.warn("Required parameter 'title' not configured for component {}",
            request.getRequestContext().getResolvedSiteMapItem().getHstComponentConfiguration().getName());
        request.setAttribute("error", "Component not properly configured");
        return;
    }

    // Optional parameter with default
    int maxItems = 10;
    if (limit != null) {
        try {
            maxItems = Integer.parseInt(limit);
        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
            logger.warn("Invalid limit parameter: {}", limit);
        }
    }

    request.setAttribute("title", title);
    request.setAttribute("maxItems", maxItems);
}
```

**Common HST Parameters to Check**:
- Document picker paths
- Query parameters
- Display settings (limit, offset)
- Configuration flags
- Custom component settings

**Related Community Issues**:
- NullPointerException in component rendering
- "Component not displaying" (due to NPE in doBeforeRender)
- Parameters working locally but not on server

**HST Component Configuration**:
Component parameters are configured in repository at:
```
/hst:hst/hst:configurations/[project]/hst:components/[component]
  + hst:parameternames = ['param1', 'param2']
  + hst:parametervalues = ['value1', 'value2']
```

**References**:
- [HST Component Development](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [Component Parameters Guide](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
WARNING Line 58:37
Parameter 'request' used without null check
config.component-parameter-null Configuration Problems
Show details 
The component parameter 'request' is accessed via getPublicRequestParameter()
and stored in variable 'asOfDate', but used without null checking.

**Risk**: HIGH - NullPointerException if parameter not configured

**Why This Happens**:
- Parameter not configured in CMS UI
- Typo in parameter name
- Component used in different context without configuration
- Configuration not published yet
- Parameter removed during refactoring

**Problem Pattern**:
```java
// ⚠️ PROBLEM - No null check
String value = getParameter("myParam");
result.setText(value.toUpperCase()); // NPE if value is null!
```

**Correct Patterns**:

**1. Simple Null Check** (Recommended):
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
if (value != null) {
    result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
} else {
    // Provide default or skip
    result.setText("Default Value");
}
```

**2. Early Return**:
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
if (value == null) {
    logger.warn("Parameter 'myParam' not configured");
    return;
}
result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
```

**3. Default Value**:
```java
String value = getParameter("myParam");
String safeValue = (value != null) ? value : "defaultValue";
result.setText(safeValue.toUpperCase());
```

**4. Optional Pattern** (Modern Java):
```java
Optional.ofNullable(getParameter("myParam"))
    .map(String::toUpperCase)
    .ifPresent(result::setText);
```

**5. Apache Commons** (if available):
```java
String value = StringUtils.defaultString(getParameter("myParam"), "default");
result.setText(value.toUpperCase());
```

**Best Practices**:
- Document required parameters in component class JavaDoc
- Log warnings when required parameters are missing
- Provide sensible defaults where possible
- Use parameter validation in doBeforeRender()
- Consider creating a ParametersInfo class with validated parameters

**Example: Robust Parameter Handling**:
```java
@Override
public void doBeforeRender(HstRequest request, HstResponse response) {
    String title = getParameter("title");
    String limit = getParameter("limit");

    // Validate required parameters
    if (title == null) {
        logger.warn("Required parameter 'title' not configured for component {}",
            request.getRequestContext().getResolvedSiteMapItem().getHstComponentConfiguration().getName());
        request.setAttribute("error", "Component not properly configured");
        return;
    }

    // Optional parameter with default
    int maxItems = 10;
    if (limit != null) {
        try {
            maxItems = Integer.parseInt(limit);
        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
            logger.warn("Invalid limit parameter: {}", limit);
        }
    }

    request.setAttribute("title", title);
    request.setAttribute("maxItems", maxItems);
}
```

**Common HST Parameters to Check**:
- Document picker paths
- Query parameters
- Display settings (limit, offset)
- Configuration flags
- Custom component settings

**Related Community Issues**:
- NullPointerException in component rendering
- "Component not displaying" (due to NPE in doBeforeRender)
- Parameters working locally but not on server

**HST Component Configuration**:
Component parameters are configured in repository at:
```
/hst:hst/hst:configurations/[project]/hst:components/[component]
  + hst:parameternames = ['param1', 'param2']
  + hst:parametervalues = ['value1', 'value2']
```

**References**:
- [HST Component Development](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)
- [Component Parameters Guide](https://xmdocumentation.bloomreach.com/)

```java
@Override
public void doBeforeRender(HstRequest request, HstResponse response) {
    String title = getParameter("title");
    String limit = getParameter("limit");

    // Validate required parameters
    if (title == null) {
        logger.warn("Required parameter 'title' not configured for component {}",
            request.getRequestContext().getResolvedSiteMapItem().getHstComponentConfiguration().getName());
        request.setAttribute("error", "Component not properly configured");
        return;
    }

    // Optional parameter with default
    int maxItems = 10;
    if (limit != null) {
        try {
            maxItems = Integer.parseInt(limit);
        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
            logger.warn("Invalid limit parameter: {}", limit);
        }
    }

    request.setAttribute("title", title);
    request.setAttribute("maxItems", maxItems);
}
```

```java
@Override
public void doBeforeRender(HstRequest request, HstResponse response) {
    String title = getParameter("title");
    String limit = getParameter("limit");

    // Validate required parameters
    if (title == null) {
        logger.warn("Required parameter 'title' not configured for component {}",
            request.getRequestContext().getResolvedSiteMapItem().getHstComponentConfiguration().getName());
        request.setAttribute("error", "Component not properly configured");
        return;
    }

    // Optional parameter with default
    int maxItems = 10;
    if (limit != null) {
        try {
            maxItems = Integer.parseInt(limit);
        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
            logger.warn("Invalid limit parameter: {}", limit);
        }
    }

    request.setAttribute("title", title);
    request.setAttribute("maxItems", maxItems);
}
```

```java
@Override

    String title = getParameter("title");
    String limit = getParameter("limit");

    // Validate required parameters
    if (title == null) {
        logger.warn("Required parameter 'title' not configured for component {}",
            request.getRequestContext().getResolvedSiteMapItem().getHstComponentConfiguration().getName());

        }

    request.setAttribute("maxItems", maxItems);
```

```java
@Override

    String title = getParameter("title");
    String limit = getParameter("limit");

    // Validate required parameters
    if (title == null) {
        logger.warn("Required parameter 'title' not configured for component {}",
            request.getRequestContext().getResolvedSiteMapItem().getHstComponentConfiguration().getName());

        }

    request.setAttribute("title", title);
    request.setAttribute("maxItems", maxItems);
}
```
